title: 104_s1265
content: The "Community Food Security Act of 1995" may be cited as the short title. Assistance is provided for community food security projects. The "Community Food Security Act of 1995" provides assistance for community food security projects, defined as initiatives that aim to meet the food needs of low-income individuals, increase community self-reliance in food provision, and address local food, farm, and nutrition issues comprehensively. Eligible entities are those with experience in this area. The "Community Food Security Act of 1995" authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to provide grants to eligible entities with experience in community food work or job training for food-related businesses in low-income communities. The Secretary may assist in establishing and carrying out community food security projects through grant funding. Eligible entities must demonstrate competency in implementing such projects. The Secretary of Agriculture provides grants to eligible entities with experience in community food work. Projects must demonstrate competency, fiscal accountability, data collection, and willingness to share information. Preference is given to projects that develop linkages between food system sectors and support entrepreneurial solutions to local food problems. The Federal government provides grants for community food security projects, with a requirement that the Federal share of costs does not exceed 50%. The non-Federal share can be provided in cash or in kind from private, State, or local sources. Each project can only receive a single grant for a specified term. The Secretary provides technical assistance, information sharing, and participates in assessments for community food security projects. The evaluation of these projects is also required. The Secretary must evaluate community food security projects funded under this section and submit a report to Congress by January 30, 2000. $4,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1996 to 2000 for this purpose.
